14.text: How've I ended up like this

72.text: Just letting you know I've got out of the possession hearing

76.text: Yeah, judge ordered possession to be suspended on 28 days

80.text: on terms that she pays her rent plus £5 per week off the arrears

85.text: Yeah, it's a shame. We did give her every opportunity to work with us

89.text: but we'll just have to see how she goes.

91.text: I'll try and make contact with her when I get back to the office and let her know the outcome.

96.text: If she doesn't maintain her payments though, we'll have to apply to the court for an eviction.

121.text: Well it was working fine yesterday

127.text: So I've got to pay for the repairs myself?

150.text: Can't believe she's let it get to this stage.

153.text: I know how hard you two have worked to engage with her but I really think we need to give her just one more chance.

160.text: Do you think you could try and get in touch with her again?

167.text: Hiya, it's Amanda calling from Mosscare.

169.text: I've been trying to get hold of you for a few weeks to discuss your rent arrears.

173.text: As you know, we obtained an order for possession which was suspended

177.text: on terms that your pay your rent plus five pounds every week towards your arrears

180.text: but from looking at your account we've not received any payments from you

185.text: that means that we're going to have to apply for a warrant for an eviction.

188.text: Yeah, I know. I'm really sorry.

191.text: Things just haven't been going well lately.

193.text: Is there anything I can do to stop that happening?

197.text: If you agree to pay us £500 today to cover what you should have paid for the last 4 weeks

202.text: we won't have to apply for an eviction and we can look to make another arrangement with you.

207.text: Is that something you think you'd be able to manage?

210.text: Yeah, I should. I just got paid today so I should be able to do it later.

227.text: Can't believe she's let it get to this stage, to be honest.

234.text: I'll notify allocations to say that a void property's going to be coming up.

239.text: Yeah, and I'll speak to the homeless team at social services

242.text: to inform them there's two children involved

245.text: And I'll get this in the post.

249.text: Oh, there's a house on here  that looks just like yours.

251.text: I think I'm going to bid for it.

255.text: Erm, just have a look at this.

257.text: Isn't that your house? Look at the curtains.

263.text: What's my house doing on Manchester Move for bidding on?

269.text: They must be going to evict me!

271.text: No, you'll be fine. You've got kids, they'll never evict you.

274.text: Just say you'll pay £2 a week or something.

279.text: Remember that Sheila down the road?

281.text: She owed them thousands. I'm sure she was only paying back like £3 a week or something.

285.text: Call them tomorrow and say to take your house off Manchester Move

289.text: or else you're going to get your solicitor involved.

300.text: Yes, Miss Richards. It's going to happen today.

306.text: No, sorry. That wouldn't be enough.

309.text: At this stage you will have to pay the arrears in full plus court costs.

313.text: Well, what else can I do?

315.text: Can I £3 a week? I know someone who does that for you.

318.text: I'm sorry, no. You need to pay the arrears in full and

322.text: court costs. You will need to go to the court to suspend the warrant.

326.text: Look, I'll have to call you back.

328.text: I'm sure I can sort something but I've got to go to work. I'm already late.

349.text: How've I ended up like this?
